@iamwillcannon It's very tempting to solve multiple problems at once.  But you have to resist.

You'll spread everyone thin, & you'll end up being ok (or worse) at everything, rather than great at something.  

The key is to get great at ONE thing & milk it completely.  

Then, expand outward.

RT @BoringSaaSGuy: The key to startup success is co-building products with customers

Don't let it come back to bite you, as it did for us.  

Focus on Customer Success early.

I don't care what business you are in -- you need to make sure the maximum percentage of customers are reaching their desired outcome with your product or service.  

So, are you measuring this?  

Is this a metric you and your team is prioritizing?

The lesson here is that Sales will keep you alive.  

It will validate that people will buy your vision.  

But it will not not cure all.

You can't go on forever like this, because people will start writing negative reviews and a bigger hole will be dug.  Everything will become more difficult than it has to be.

Eventually, we fixed this and created a phenomenal company.

We realized there was a TON of work yet to be done.  

People were getting lost when onboarding, they were using the software incorrectly and giving up, our documentation was lacking, and on and on...

Customer Success can be summed up as how many customers reach their "desired outcome" as a result of using your product.

Well, It turned out that half our customers were not reaching their desired outcome.

So we began calling them, talking to as many as we could.

At the 1 year mark, the cancellation requests started rolling in.  

Month after month, we were seeing 50% of the customers churn.  

This is when I learned some brutal lessons about Customer Success.

My sales team was primarily selling 1 year packages to our software.  

This was and is fantastic - you validate that what you are selling is resonating, and you get a ton of cash up front.  

The problem is that you think you have product-market fit, and you don't - yet.

Sales cures all - until it doesn't.

I learned this the hard way.  

One of my startups sold $524k in it's first year.

I brought out the champagne, and started celebrating early.  What could go wrong?  

It turns out, everything.  

Here's what happened:

‚ÄúA players hire other A players.  B players hire other B and C players.‚Äù ‚Äî Steve Jobs

This is why it is so important to start at the top of every department.  To get an A player leading it.

If you don't, all you will have is other B & C players running the department, and...

If there is an important metric not going in the right direction, you should immediately establish a daily 15-minute review meeting with the key players.

The daily focus will get it back on track quickly.

Once on track, dial it back to weekly.  

Then monthly, and so forth.

But if it‚Äôs a one-way door, analyze it five different ways. Be careful, because that is where slow is smooth and smooth is fast.

You do not want to make one-way-door decisions quickly. You want to get consensus or at least drive a lot of thought and debate."

When there‚Äôs a decision that needs to be made, you need to ask, ‚ÄúIs it a one-way door or a two-way door?‚Äù 

If it‚Äôs a two-way door, make the decision with a small team or even one high-judgment individual. 

Make the decision. If it‚Äôs wrong, it‚Äôs wrong. You‚Äôll change it.

And what happens in large organizations‚Äînot in start-up companies but in large organizations‚Äîis that all decisions end up using the heavyweight process that is really intended only for irreversible, highly consequential decisions. 

And that‚Äôs a disaster.
